titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Brian Carpenter

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T21:16-0400

did.unittitle: Materials Recorded at Copper Center, Alaska
did.abstract: Field recordings made in Chistochina and Copper Center, Alaska in 1960. Includes potlatch songs, love songs, Christmas tree songs, sorry songs, dance songs, and others. Some songs Yakutat Tlingit, Upper Tanana, or Tanacross. Also includes some Ahtna vocabulary.
did.physdesc: 9 sound tape reels (6 hr., 22 min.) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Frederica de Laguna and accessioned in 1962 (1961 961r).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Permission required for access to materials. Please consult the Manuscripts Librarian for details.

did.unittitle: Songs and conversation at Chistochina, Alaska, July 23, 1960 [2 of 2]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two potlatch songs, with conversation. Recording ends with summary information and corrections by Frederica de Laguna. "The potlatch song is sung when everybody stands and sways from side to side, arms folded, and wishes for good luck. Each potlatch song is composed for a special occasion, and is sung once at the potlatch by the assembly. It then becomes the property of the host's clan and may not be sung by another clan unless they pay for it - $10-20."

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: This file is a compressed, digitized version of the original. The APS Library maintains the original format (Sound tape reel) as well as an uncompressed digitized version of this recording.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "This song is apparently one sung by guests at a potlatch after they have been fed. In it they claim they have eaten as gluttonousely as the crows of the song." The song is played twice, the second time with a different microphone.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "This is the song to which a masked man dances to frighten naughty children at potlatch time. He is generally compared to Santa Claus."

did.unittitle: Paul Joe's Sorry Song for Chief Peter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Made for the Potlatch of Chief Peter Tetlin, September 1958. Re-recording of song recorded earlier in the month. See Related Recording.
